# DV is crit_part, IV is house_distance_dim1

mod10 <- glm(crit_part ~ Inst_Cred_Gallup + House_distance_dim1 + AuthRank + Source, family=binomial(link="logit"), data=slimdata)
summary(mod10)

mod10robust <- robustify(mod10, cluster=Author)
summary(mod10robust)

mod10mixed <- glmer(crit_part ~ Inst_Cred_Gallup + House_distance_dim1 + AuthRank + Source + (1 | Author), family=binomial, data=slimdata)
summary(mod10mixed)

# DV is crit_part, IV is aff_polar_alt

mod12 <- glm(crit_part ~ Inst_Cred_Gallup + aff_polar_alt + AuthRank + Source, family=binomial(link="logit"), data=slimdata)
summary(mod12)

mod12robust <- robustify(mod12, cluster=Author)
summary(mod12robust)

mod12mixed <- glmer(crit_part ~ Inst_Cred_Gallup + aff_polar_alt + AuthRank + Source + (1 | Author), family=binomial, data=slimdata)
summary(mod12mixed)

```

The dependent variable is a binary indicator of whether the opinion piece challenged one of the three norms of civil-military relations by strongly criticizing a civilian leader, adopting an expressly partisan position, or addressing a topic that falls outside of policy areas that are directly relevant to military expertise. I control for the rank of the author as well as the source in which an opinion piece was published to control for newspaper sources which may have adopted a more-pronounced ideological bent along the liberal - conservative spectrum as polarization has worsened [for an informative view of where media outlets are along such a spectrum, see @noauthor_allsides_nodate]. Due to complete separation between the dependent variable involving observations published in _The Los Angeles Times_ and _USA Today_, these 11 observations are dropped from the regression analysis.^[I include several types of models, including a regular logit model, a logit model that clusters standard errors at the author level, and a mixed model that introduces random effects at the author level. The intent of the models which cluster standard errors or introduce random effects at the author level is to determine the degree to which the data can distinguish if the individual authors themselves are an important determinant of whether an opinion piece challenges one of the norms of civil-military relations. The logit model without clustered errors at the author level assumes that authors have no distinguishing characteristics that would incline them towards behavior that would result in the dependent variable taking on a value of 1, whereas both the mixed model with author random effects and the logit model that clusters errors at the author level allows for the possibility that individual author characteristics may explain the dependent variable in important ways that the model does not otherwise account for.] The results are displayed in Table \@ref(tab:regression1) below. 

\singlespace
```{r Regression Results, include=TRUE, echo=FALSE, results="asis", warning=FALSE, message=FALSE}
stargazer(mod9, mod9robust, mod9mixed, mod11, mod11robust, mod11mixed,
          type="latex",
          label="tab:regression1",
          title="Regression Results", 
          covariate.labels = c('Mil Cred', 'Cong. Polar', 'Aff. Polar', 'Rank', 'SourceWaPo'),
          dep.var.caption = "Odds (log) of Opinion Commentary Authored by Retired Military Officers",
          dep.var.labels = "Challenging Normative Standards of Military Behavior",
          model.names=TRUE,
          header=FALSE,
          column.sep.width = "-15pt",
          align=TRUE)
         
```
\doublespace
The results shown in Table \@ref(tab:regression1) indicate that across all model specifications, the coefficient for polarization, regardless of how it is measured, is statistically significant.  Substantively, a coefficient of .118 for Congressional Polarization in Models 1 and 2 indicate that a one unit increase in the mean ideological distance between political parties in Congress is associated with a 12.5 percent increase in the odds that a commentary publication authored by a retired military officer challenges or violates one of the normative standards of military behavior - the principle of civilian control, non-partisanship, or "non-interference" of the military into policy realms that deviate from military relevant military expertise. Similarly, the coefficient for affective polarization in Models 4 and 5 of .045 indicate that for every one unit increase the level of disdain for partisans to feel for those members who affiliate with the other side, there is a 4.6 percent increase in the odds that a retired military officer violates or pushes up against a normative standard in the opinion commentary he or she publishes.  

While the coefficients for the different measurements of polarization are of different size, scaling these measures to understand how each measure shifts over time is important. For instance, within the House of Representatives in the 112th Congress, which began in January 2011, polarization levels were nearly six points higher than the level that existed in the 111th Congress. Such a drastic change in the polarization level within Congress would predict a roughly 75 percent increase in the odds of an opinion publication authored by a retired military officer strongly criticizing a civilian leader, taking a clear partisan stance, or addressing a topic that falls outside of relevant military experience. Regarding changes in the levels of affective polarization, data from the 2012 ANES indicate that the aggregate level of affective polarization increased by just over 16 points from the previous Presidential Election year (2008), which would correspond to a 73.6 percent increase in the odds of a publication authored by a retired military officer violating one of the three foundational norms of civil-military relations. Thus, the coefficients for the respective levels of polarization turn out to be substantively very similar, which increases the confidence that the theory underlying these predictions works in the ways in which it is anticipated to. 

In terms of the other coefficients besides measurements of polarization, two points are worth underscoring. The first is that the coefficients for the estimated impacts of military prestige are negative and not statistically significant across all six models. Relative to the statistical significance and positive direction of the coefficients for polarization, we conclude that changes in military credibility have less explanatory power, if any, in whether a publication authored by retired military officers fails to adhere to norms of civilian control, non-partisanship, and non-interference. The second interesting point is that the coefficients for the author's rank and the source in which a commentary piece is published are both statistically insignificant across all of the models. These results refute alternative explanations which suggest a retired military officer's rank is a driving factor in leading an author to challenge a normative standard in the opinion material he or she publishes, or that a particular newspaper source is significantly more likely than the others examined to publish an opinion piece which challenges or violates normative standards. 

Finally, it is important to note that in Models 3 and 6, which are both mixed models that include random effects at the author level in order to allow for the possibility that individual authors are driving results in the dependent variable rather than other variables, the coefficients for the respective measurements of polarization increase relative to other model types, but also drop in statistical significance. These models, therefore, lead to the conclusion that as polarization increases, it is having a greater impact on certain individual authors, who in turn challenging normative standards through the opinion publications which they author. 

## Predicted Probability

Using the regression results from Table \@ref(tab:regression1) to transform the results of our logistic regressions into predicted probabilities, we can plot the predicted probability of retired military opinion commentary violating normative standards as the level of polarization changes. Using the results of the logistic regression from Model 4, which includes a measure of affective polarization, the source is set for _The New York Times_, while values of the institutional credibility of the military and author rank are held fixed at their respective means (71.1 and 8.39). These predicted probabilities are graphed in Figure \@ref(fig:pred-prob-ANES) below. 

```{r predicted probabilities, include=FALSE, warning=FALSE, message=FALSE, error=FALSE}

# Use Model 11 (Logit) from Above, where IV is aff_polar, and there are no author random Effects
# Hold values of Author Rank and Institutional Credibility at their mean
# Vary the Level of Affective Polarization from its minimum value to an arbitrary 
# level of 120, which is higher than it currently is but not theoretically impossible.  

predictiondata <- tibble(aff_polar_alt=seq(min(slimdata$aff_polar_alt), 120, by=1), Inst_Cred_Gallup = mean(slimdata$Inst_Cred_Gallup), Source="NYT", AuthRank=mean(slimdata$AuthRank)) %>% crossing(crit_part = c(0,1))

predictiondata
augment(mod11, newdata = predictiondata, se_fit=TRUE)

# prediction data
predictions <- augment(mod12, newdata=predictiondata, se_fit=TRUE) %>% 
  mutate(
    .prob=plogis(.fitted),
    conf.low = plogis(.fitted - (qnorm(.975) * .se.fit)),
    conf.high = plogis(.fitted + (qnorm(.975) * .se.fit)),
    pred_final_rec = case_when(
      .prob >= .5 ~ "Likely",
      .prob < .5 ~ " Not likely"
    )
  )

predictions %>% arrange(.prob, .fitted, crit_part, desc(.fitted)) %>% 
  view()

# now let's try some graphs
# notice that the predictions are not in (0, 1)
ggplot(predictions) +
  aes(x = .fitted) +
  geom_histogram()

# if we wanted predictions on the probability scale,
#   we predict on the log scale,
#   then apply inverse-logit (logistic CDF)
# use plogis(): cumulative probability of the logistic distribution

# demonstration: scatter log odds (x) and predicted probability (y)
# with 95% CIs
# (CIs don't look smooth in this example because .se.fit depends on X data)
predictions %>%
  ggplot() +
  aes(x = .fitted, y = .prob) +
  geom_pointrange(aes(ymin = conf.low, ymax = conf.high)) +
  geom_smooth() 

```

Figure \@ref(fig:pred-prob-ANES) clearly reveals that the probability of retired military officer commentary violating normative standards rises as the level of affective polarization among the US electorate increases. Regardless of the specific point estimates of probability revealed in Figure \@ref(fig:pred-prob-ANES), the more consequential and important takeaway is that if polarization remains - and all signs are that it will, at least in the short term - the commentary and dialogue offered by retired military officers to the American public will consistently challenge normative standards.

Collectively, the results offer mixed support for the four hypotheses this chapter set out to explore. The chapter provides strong support for H1, which theorized that military elites are less united ideologically during periods of high polarization relative to periods of low polarization. The instances with which retired military officers challenged or expressly violated one or more of the three normative standards of behavior greatly increased as polarization rose over time, indicating that like the public, military elites feel very strongly about certain ideological issues or sets of issues, and are willing to address these issues, and even strongly criticize civilian leadership or express partisan positions in doing so. 

The chapter found mixed support for H2, which hypothesized that military elites are increasingly active in a partisan manner when polarization was high relative to periods of low polarization. The data indicate that while elites certainly were increasingly active in a partisan sense as polarization increased, there were also isolated periods when military elites were active in a partisan sense when polarization was relatively low. In the data, one of these periods was the 2004 time frame, when several retired military officers endorsed candidates for President in the Press, or took to denouncing or supporting former Secretary of Defense Donald Rumsfeld. 

I find mixed support for H3, which hypothesized that military elites are more assertive and thus, are willing to challenge civilian authority during periods of high military prestige relative to periods when military prestige is low. The data clearly support this general trend, but the quantitative analysis revealed that the independent variable of polarization holds more explanatory power than that of military prestige in driving retired military officers to challenge civilian authority by offering blunt and pointed criticism in published opinion commentary. 

Finally, I find mixed support for H4, which hypothesized that military elites increasingly challenge civilian authorities in a visible, public manner during periods of high military prestige relative to periods of low military prestige. Here again, the data seem to generally support such a trend, but more analysis is required to determine if military actors are deliberately choosing to engage in behaviors that are increasingly visible rather than other, less-visible forms of behavior during the same time period. Ideally, qualitative case studies which isolate the varying levels of polarization and military prestige will further bear this out. 

# Can A Military Be Professional In an Era of Polarization?

This study demonstrated that although the vast number of opinion publications authored by retired military officers uphold the foundational principles and norms that have been the hallmark of American civil-military relations for decades, retired military elites are increasingly failing to uphold these norms in a significant portion of the messaging that they conduct with the American public. Specifically, the written opinion commentary which retired military officers publish in major US newspapers is increasingly challenging, if not expressly violating, one ore more of the principles of civilian control of the military, non-partisanship of the military institution, and a norm of "non-interference" of the military into certain realms of state policy. 

This study supports the general theory that among the pernicious consequences of polarization is a weakening in the ability of foundational normative standards of civil-military relations to constrain members of the military institution from engaging in certain forms of behavior, likely for similar reasons that polarization is dividing the American public. Not only does polarization reflect different policy preferences for a number of important political topics, which is routine in everyday domestic politics, but high levels of polarization also indicate that strong divisions exist regarding the worldviews, values, and overall purposes that should govern society. Military actors may genuinely desire to stay as politically neutral as possible, but as they encounter challenges with increasing frequency and in which a stark difference in consequences between two competing courses of action are present, they are increasingly likely to choose the dictates of personal conscience, even if doing so violates or challenges their professional duties [@cohn_what_2019].

Does it really matter if retired military officers write opinion commentary that pushes the boundaries of normative standards of behavior? Does it matter if today's retired military officers simply see the issue of expressing their opinions publicly differently than the Omar Bradley's of decades ago? Research has already confirmed that some citizens, especially partisans who strongly identify with a political affiliation, are happy when a retired military officer publicly quarrels with an elected official of the opposite political party, a trend that we know is becoming more problematic in an age of polarization [@robinson_michael_danger_2018]. A less explored impact, and one worthy of future research, is whether and to what degree increased retired office dialogue has on those who still serve in the active duty military. For many officers, the retired generals and admirals who are pushing the boundaries of normative standards are the former bosses and leaders with whom leaders in the active duty force once served. There is a risk that those still serving will view the behavior of retired military officers as increasingly normatively appropriate, which could risk these officers on active duty engaging in the same. 

Even if this were not to occur, the fact is that retired military officers have a lot of experience, much of which can be helpful in illuminating the knowledge of the public, especially when issues that involve operations are concerned. Instances in which a retired military officer criticizes a civilian official indiscriminately, adopts a partisan stance, or addresses a topic that is tangential to his or her military experience is a lost opportunity to engage the public on a topic that may be more beneficial in the short term. More seriously, it may have long-term consequences not just on the level of trust that Americans place in the military, but on the propensity of those serving in, and who will join, the active duty military, to disregard normative standards of behavior altogether.

## Word and Data-Base Searches to Obtain Data

I did two different sets of searches.  This first set of search terms was applied to the Factiva and Nexus-Uni data bases. In each of these databases, I had to select the "type of article" and included options such as commentary/opinion and letters to the editor.
The specific terms of search included:

"retired Army General" or "former Army General" or "retired Navy Admiral" or "former Navy Admiral" or "retired Marine Corps General" or "former Marine Corps General" or "former Air Force General" or "retired Air Force General" or "retired Coast Guard Admiral" or "former Coast Guard Admiral" or "retired from the Marine Corps" or "retired from the Army" or "retired from the Navy" or "retired from the Air Force" or "retired from the Coast Guard" or "supreme commander of" or "commander of" or "Chairman of the Joint Chiefs" or "chairman of the joint chiefs" or "Supreme Commander of" or "Chief of Staff" or "Chief of Naval Operations" or "retired Army" or "retired Navy" or "retired Air Force" or "retired Marine Corps" or "retired Coast Guard" or "retired military" or "commandant of" or "director of" or "retired from the military"

The second set of search terms was applied to Pro Quest Historical Newspapers, which the University of Wisconsin had access to for both the Wall Street Journal and the New York Times. Factiva included article from the Wall Street Journal only back to the middle of 1994, so I relied heavily on Pro Quest to search through the Wall Street Journal from 1979-1994. Unlike the search terms used for Factiva and Nexus-Uni, however, I came to quickly realize that the opinion pieces I sought were not categorized as opinion-editorials or letters to the editor, but rather as "articles."  This required significantly more time searching for the desired data, as more articles had to be searched through and sifted. The specific terms of search included:

(retired OR former OR “chief of staff”) AND (“Army General” OR Gen. OR general OR "Navy Admiral" OR Adm. OR admiral OR "Marine Corps General" OR "Coast Guard Admiral" OR "Air Force General" OR "Chairman of the Joint Chiefs" OR "colonel" OR "captain" OR "commander" OR "chief of naval operations" OR "commandant" OR "director of")
